dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is bare, dusty. A ceiling fan turns. The  wall clock ticks. Craig, 30 years old and small, sits at a collapsible card table. The only item on the table is a book. Craig picks it up, looks at the jacket. It's entitl "Sit." Craig opens the book. It reads: "sit sit sit sit sit..." over and over, page after page. Craig closes the book. He begins to stand, but thinks better of it, sighs. He looks at the book again. It is now entitled "Die."  He opens it up.  "die die die die die..."  A rooster crows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig jolts awake. A rooster stands on Craig's chest, crowing. Lotte, also 30, in the middle of dressing for  work, hurries in and pulls the bird from Craig's chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, hon. I didn't know Orrin Hatch was out of his pen. Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte leans down and kisses Craig on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta run. Shipment of grub worms coming in first thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enjoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig, listen, honey, I've been thinking... maybe you'd feel better if you got, you know, a job or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been over this. Nobody's looking for a puppeteer in today's wintry economic climate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know, maybe something else until this whole puppet thing turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) The Great Mantini doesn't need a day job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Craig, everyone can't be Derek Mantini. (beat) Well, grub worms are waiting. Do me a favor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you check in on Elijah? He seems to be a little under the weather this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one is Elijah again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The monkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is a mess. Vivaldi blasts through cheap speaker A small marionette stage stands in the back of the garage The stage is lit and on it is a finely sculpted puppet  version of Craig. The "Craig" puppet paces back and forth wringing its hands with incredible subtlety. We see Craig above and behind the stage. He is manipulating the puppet His fingers move fast and furious. The puppet breaks into a dance, a beautiful and intricate balletic piece. Soon t puppet is leaping and tumbling through space, moves that would think impossible for a marionette. Sweat appears on the real CraigВ’s brow. His fingers move like lightning. puppet moves faster and faster. Sweat appears on the pupp brow. We see that the sweat is being piped from a special device that the real Craig controls. The Craig puppet collapses on the floor of the stage. It puts its hands up its face and weeps. Craig hangs the puppet, and comes dow around the front of the stage. He is heaving. He switches off the music, picks up a beer and takes a swig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is filled with penned and unpenned animals of al kinds: snakes, lizards, birds, a dog, cats, etc. Craig si on the couch and looks at the want ads, the TV is on in t background. Elijah, the monkey, sits next to Craig holdin his stomach and moaning weakly. On the TV, Derek Mantini working a 60 foot high marionette from the top of a water The assembled crowd is enthralled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd is enthralled as Derek Mantini, arguably the greatest puppeteer in the history of the  world, performs "The Belle of Amherst" with his 60 foot Emily Dickinson puppet, directed by the inimitable Charles Nelson Reilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Nelson Reilly floats by in a hot air balloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful, beautiful! Nyong-nyong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimmicky bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig switches off the TV. He comes across an ad for a female puppeteer to teach at a girls school. Craig rubs  his chin in thought, then stands with great determination

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig searches through Lotte's closet, looking for the right dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig waxes his body, shaves his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig paints his nails while he chats on the phone. Craig pulls stockings and underwear from Lotte's drawer. Craig  picks a wig from a mannequin head on Lotte's dressing tab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig, at the sewing machine, is sewing padding to go ont his chest and around his hips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig applies make up in the bathroom mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig, now looking very much like a woman, admires himsel in the full length mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig hails a taxi in his get-up. Men on the street turn and leer at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. HEADMISTRESSВ’S OFFICE - DAY Craig and the headmistress chat over tea. Craig is quite animated and charming. The admiring headmistress smiles  and nods her head in approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig instructs a class of uniformed girls. He draws complex diagrams of puppets on the blackboard. The students are transfixed, except for one troubled girl who eyes Craig sullenly from the back of the room as she play with a switchblade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig guides the hands of the troubled teenage girl, who is trying to manipulate a marionette. The girl looks up at Craig. Her tough facade crumbles and she smiles. Craig smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls carry Craig on their shoulders. Everyone is joy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig leads the girls in a bike race. Everyone is laughin and screaming. One of the girls notices that Craig is riding a man's bike. MUSIC OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig sits in a holding cell with several other men. He i still in the dress, but the wig is in his lap and the make-up is smeared off. Lotte appears with a cop outside Craig's cell. The door is opened, and Craig, Lotte, and the cop head down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte drives. Craig looks out the window. Both are silent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) Is the trial date set?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May 11th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you do it, Craig?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a puppeteer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig sits on the couch in his bathrobe and studies the want ads. He sees an ad for a company called "WOMYN-TEERS looking for "an African-American, Lesbian Separatist Puppeteer for Community Outreach." Craig rubs his chin in thought, stands with determination. MUSIC IN: SAME AS BEFORE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig applies a dark pancake make-up to his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig pulls an afro-style wig off a mannequin head on Lotte's dressing table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig, now made up to look like a black, lesbian separatist, hails a cab. Women look at him longingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig, dressed as the black lesbian and beaten to a pulp. sits in the passenger seat. Lotte drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) Why, Craig. why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through fat lip) I... puppeteer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig reads the paper. He comes across an ad: "Female puppeteer wanted for nudist colony marionette staging of 'Oh, Calcutta!'"  Craig rubs his chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig sits in the passenger seat. He is made up as a woman and wears a full-body rubber "naked woman" suit. Lotte drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) You know, maybe you should speak to someone about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig sees a personal ad: "Male puppeteer looking for attractive female puppeteer for friendship, travel, and much much more."  Craig rubs his chin, then thinks better of it and sighs. He finds a want ad calling for a "short-statured file clerk with unusually nimble and dexterous fingers needed for speed filing."  Craig writes down the address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig. in sport coat and tie, studies the business listin board. He finds LesterCorp, and sees that it is located o floor 7 1/2. Craig presses the elevator button and waits. Another man comes and waits next to him. The doors open, and Craig and the other man get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other man presses "9." Craig studies the buttons. The is no "7 1/2."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven and a half, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh. yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take you through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man picks up a crowbar leaning in the corner. He watches the floor numbers light up in succession. After "7" and before "8", the man hits the emergency stop butto The elevator slams to a halt. The man pries open the door with the crowbar. Revealed is a standard office building hallway, except that from floor to ceiling it is only abo four feet high. Everything is scaled down accordingly. The number on the wall across from the elevator is 7 1/2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven and a half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig climbs out onto the 7 1/2 floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig, hunched-over, makes his way down the hallway looking for LesterCorp. He passes a hunched-over man walking in the other direction. They nod to each other. Craig finds a door marked "LesterCorp - Meeting America's Filing Needs Since 1922."  He enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All furniture is scaled down to fit into this low-ceiling space. A few other short men sit reading tiny magazines. Craig approaches Floris, the receptionist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to LesterCorp. May we meet your filing needs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, uh, my name is Craig Schwartz. I have an interview with Mr. Lester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please have a seat, Mr. Juarez...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schwartz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schwartz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm afraid I have no idea what you're saying right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Schwartz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money, Miss Warts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig takes a seat next to the other applicants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling across the room) Fork ah did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The intercom buzzes. Floris picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Craig) Mr. Juarez?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said "yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You suggest what? I have no time for piddling suggestions from mumbling job applicants, my good man. Besides, Dr. Lester will see you now. I think that's what he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig stands, opens Lester's door, and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig enters. Lester, a giant of an old man, sits hunched behind his tiny desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, Mr. Juarez. I'd stand, but, well, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extending his hand) Actually, my name is Craig Schwartz, Dr. Lester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester flips an intercom switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Security.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's okay, sir. Just a mixup with your secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not my secretary. She's what they call an executive liaison, and I'm not banging her, if that's what youВ’re implying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all, Dr. Lester. I simply misspoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Dr. Schwartz, what do you feel you can bring to LesterCorp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, I'm an excellent filer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crafty) You think so, eh? Which comes first, L or... Glooph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glooph is not a letter, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, you are good. I tried to trick you. Okay, put these in order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester hands Craig a bunch of index cards. Craig orders them with amazing speed and dexterity. Lester watches, eyes wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flips intercom switch) Floris, get Guinness on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gehginnis ondah foam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fork ah did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flips off switch) Fine woman, Floris. I don't know how she puts up with this damn speech impediment of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have a speech impediment, Dr. Lester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flattery will get you everywhere, my boy. But I'm afraid I have to trust Floris on this one. You see, she has her doctorate in speech impedimentology from Case Western. Perhaps you've read her memoirs, "I can't understand a word any of you are saying."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pity, it tells it like it is. That's why the eastern, read Jewish, publishing establishment won't touch it. That's a quote from the book jacket. George Will, I think. (beat) I apologize if you can't understan a word I'm saying, Dr. Schwartz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I understand perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (choking up) Thank you for being kind enough to lie. You see, I've been very lonely in my isolated tower of indecipherable speech. You're hired. Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one. Why is this floor so short?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low overhead, m'boy. We pass the savings on to you. (laughs heartily) But seriously, that's all covered in orientation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a small screening room with red velvet seats. There are a few people scattered about the squat theater. Craig is among them. He looks around the room and his eyes rest momentarily on Maxine. She is in her late 20's with close cropped black hair. Her eyes are opaque, her face expressionless, her countenance trance-like. She glances over at Craig, then turns back to the screen. The lights dim. A projector whirs and the screen is illuminated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We tilt up the building. MUSIC:        Perky Industrial Film Music. TITLE:        The 7 1/2 Floor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the 7 1/2 floor of the Mertin-Flemmer building. As you will now be spending your work day here, it is important that you learn a bit about the history of this famous floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don and Wendy, two office workers, crouch in the hall and chat. Both hold cups of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Don.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don, I was wondering, do you know why our workplace has such low ceilings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an interesting story, Wendy. Many years ago in the late 1800's, James Mertin, an Irish ship captain looking to invest in the future of our great country, came to this town and decided to erect an office building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would call this building the Mertin-Flemmer Building, after himself and someone else, who, local legend has it, was named Flemmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An actor playing Mertin sits at a desk and writes with aquill. He appears very stern and has mutton chop sideburns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day. Captain Mertin received an unexpected visitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enter ye, if ye dare enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny woman enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Mertin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What want ye, girl child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not a child, Captain Mertin, but rather an adult lady of miniature proportions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) I see. Well, it is not my fault that thou art tiny. So if it is charity yer after, then be gone with ye, ye foul demon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not asking for alms, but rather the ear of a kind man with a noble heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Aye. Speak then if ye must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Mertin, surely I am a God-fearing Christian woman like yourself, but alas, I am afraid that the world was not built with me in mind. Door knobs are too high, chairs are unwieldy, high-ceilinged rooms mock my stature. Nor am I a marrie lady, Captain. after all, who would marry a person of my diminutiveness? So I am forced to work for my few pennies a week as an optometrist. Why cannot there be a place for me to work safe and comfortable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mertin wipes a tear from his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woman, your story moves me like n other. Me own sister was tiny and then died. Therefore, I shall make ye me wife. And I shall build a floor in my building, between the 7th and 8th, which will be scaled down, so from now on there shall be at least one place on God's green Earth that you and your accursed kind can live in peace...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don And Wendy crouch and talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's the story of 7 1/2. Since the rents are considerably lower this floor has been adopted by businesses which for one reason or another are forced to cut corners After all... the overhead is low! Ha ha ha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha ha ha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE:        The End

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen goes dark. The lights go up. Craig looks over at Maxine. She stands and walks past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Unfortunately it's bullshit. The real story of 7 1/2 is so evil that it could never be revealed to Americans raised on sitcoms and happy news anchors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, truth is for suckers, isn't it?.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. I'm Craig Schwartz, just starting out at LesterCorp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dreary - to be - Somebody / How public - like a Frog / To tell one's name - the livelong June / To an admiring Bog!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) Emily Dickinson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maxine walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte chops onions. A parrot sits on her head. Craig stir a pot on the stove. A monkey leaps from the top of the cabinet to the top of the refrigerator to the kitchen tab A dog watches the monkey and barks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! Shut up! Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Craig) Sorry, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog continues to bark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry honey. Sorry honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An offscreen neighbor pounds the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Sorry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte grabs the parrot off her head and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help! She's locking me in a cage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte reenters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that cute? I just taught her that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adorable. What time are they supposed to be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven-ish

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to make it an early night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll understand. Besides I've got a morning appointment tomorrow with Elijah's shrink. We're getting to the bottom of this acid stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not paying attention) Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some sort of childhood trauma, she thinks. Possible feelings of inadequacy as a chimp. Interesting, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell rings. The dog barks. The parrot screams. The neighbor pounds on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dining room table is set up. Craig and Lotte and thei friends Peter and Gloria are seated and eating dinner. Th is an obvious lull in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good food, Lotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Craig helped, too, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vegetarian, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. All vegetable. all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is another lull. Everyone eats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding about that 7 1/2 floor. Craig?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great. It almost sounds like make-believe. (beat) Like a storybook. (beat) like a fairy tale. (beat) It's really great. (beat) So Lotte, when you say all vegetable, do you mean all vegetable entire1y?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria and Peter drive in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte told me that Eskimos have a lot of words for snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder why so many.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because they have a lot of snow. Isn't that interesting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig washes the dishes. Lotte dries them. They donВ’t look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig in a cream colored suit, pours over the file cabine Floris watches from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over-enunciating) Thank you, Floris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floris shrugs, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not like the other boys we've had here. Granted, I can't understand what you're saying either, but your soft palette resonates tremendously well and you never ever constrict your epiglottis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a trained performer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swooning) Music to my ears! Whatever you said. Speak, speak, speak, my magnificent friend, speak!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig pours himself a cup of coffee. Maxine approaches with an empty cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig fills her cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I've been thinking about what you said yesterday, about the orientation film being a cover-up. I think you're on to something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And fifty other lines to get into a girl's pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, if you ever got me, you wouldn't have a clue what to do with me. That's the thing, Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maxine walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig is at his workbench, painting the finishing touches on a new puppet. It is beautiful. It is Maxine. Lotte watches quietly from  the door. A Lotte puppet hangs from a hook, tangled and dusty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New puppet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig is surprised, caught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, just an idea I had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) Just an idea I had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig hangs the puppet, stands, and switches off the ligh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, let's go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dark. Lotte snores lightly. Craig lies there with his eyes open. Quietly, he gets up and leaves the bedroom. Lotte watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig stands above the puppet stage. He is working both t Craig puppet and the Maxine puppet at the same time. The two perform a beautiful and graceful pas de deux. They finish in a passionate embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) I would too know what to do with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig files. Floris watches him from the doorway. Dr. Lester watches Floris from behind a cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what magic those fingers could work on the right В“cabinet.В” (strokes Craig's neck) Alphabetize me, baby. And don't forget, I comes before U.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floris laughs long and hard. Too long and too hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floris, you're very nice, but I'm afraid IВ’m in love with somebody else.

dialogues.text: (as Malkovich, breaking through) No! Please! (as Craig, to Malkovich) Shut up, will you? We're trying to think here. (to Maxine) It is sort of like being a puppeteer. I like that about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one would ever have to know its not him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an idea) Wait a minute! What if everybody knew? What if we presented Malkovich as the world's most complicated puppet and me as the only puppeteer sophisticated enough to work him? We'd wipe the floor with the Great Mantini!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Craiggy, that's brilliant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The worshippers are assembled. Lotte stands before them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have sinned, unwittingly, against the community. And for this I am truly sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W-w-what's it like on the inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's glorious. It's indescribable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooh, I wanna go. I wanna go. I say it's time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you're right, Terry. We're all prepared, and perhaps this Schwartz fellow is forcing our hand a bit. We will enter the portal tonight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maxine and Malkovich are furiously filling the portal with cement. Suddenly Malkovich stops and runs to the office door screaming a bloodcurdling scream. He stops just as suddenly, begins to strangle himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Craig to Malkovich) Shut up! (to Maxine) Sorry, dear, I lost control for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kissing him) It's okay, my sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go back to filling the portal. There is the sound of many shuffling feet in the hallway. The door flies open and the Malkovichians led by Lester and Lotte burst in. Malkovich and Maxine turn with a start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaaahhhh, the portal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Malkovich) You bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte lunges for Malkovich. Lester grabs her arm, holds her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Don't harm the vessel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Craig in there, I can tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand, but we must protect the vessel at all costs. (to Malkovich) Please, Craig, please step aside and allow us to have what is rightfully ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Squatter's rights, Lester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig laughs somewhat maniacally. Maxine slips her arm through Craig's, joins him in his laughter, and glances triumphantly over at Lotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now excuse us, we have an entertainment legend to create.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the cult members) Clear the way for them, my friends. They will be dealt with in due time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Malkovichians grumble and let Malkovich and Maxine exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, let's see what we can do to salvage this portal... for the sake of all that is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Malkovichians converge on the sealed portal, and begin clawing desperately at the quick-drying cement. Fingers are scraped raw, and we see smears of blood and skin on the rough gray surface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slick-looking agent answers a buzzing phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, send him right in. Don't ever keep him waiting again. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich and Maxine enter. The agent stands, holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John! Great to see you! Sorry about the cunt at reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my fiancee Maxine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The agent shakes Maxine's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great to see you, Maxine. Sorry about the cunt at reception. Please have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich and Maxine sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get you anything? Coffee? Water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Teresa, get me a chicken soup. (to Malkovich and Maxine) Chicken soup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maxine and Malkovich shake their heads "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get right to the point, Larry. I'm a puppet now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm being controlled by the world's greatest puppeteer, Craig Schwartz...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no clue) Oh yeah, he's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and I want to show off his skills by performing a one-puppet extravaganza in Reno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vegas. Can you arrange that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure. Just let me make a couple of calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cult members are still there, now with picks  shovels. They are worn out and sweaty. The portal is excavated, but it seems ragged and destroyed. Man #2 emerges from the hole, a rope tied around his waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the last of it, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester peers through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's see what we've got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester crawls into the tunnel, the door slams behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester crawls through. There is a slurping sound and a flash of light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scene is in black and white. Bombs are dropping. There is a blonde in forties clothes there. Lester views the scene through somebody's POV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, where am I? This seems so familiar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The person walks past a mirror. It's Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, I'm Hitler in the bunker! Aaaahhhh! Aaaah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We look over to see a director and camera crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm just the actor in that Twilight Zone episode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a popping sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester pops into the ditch. One of his cult members is waiting with a car, and looking hopeful. Lester sadly shakes his head "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cult members mill about, drinking coffee, chatting. Lester enters with the cult member who picked him up at the ditch. All quiet down and look over at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you all for your efforts, but I'm afraid we can no longer get into Malkovich through the portal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panicky) Why not? I need to get in there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not certain, my dear, but I believe your husband has somehow psychically diverted the route.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bastard! I'll gladly dispose of him in the name of the order, Son of Malkovich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that no physical harm must come to him as long as he inhabits the vessel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raises hand) Oooh, I got an idea! What if we build another portal to Malkovich, like around back, and sneak in that way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only Captain Mertin knew how to build a portal, dummy, and he's dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, my friends, I suppose its time I told you, I'm Captain James Mertin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The members fall into a stunned silence. Lester takes some refrigerator magnets and spells out L-E-S-T-E-R on a board. He then rearranges them for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Lester is an anagram for Mertin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester continues to rearrange the letters, getting a litt tense now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It used to work, I'm sure of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several members check their watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, damn it to hell. Anyway, I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: L-E-S-T-E-R has been left as E-L R-E-S-T as Lester turns from the board to face the congregation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can this be? I thought you were only one hundred and five years old. Mertin would have to be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckles amiably) I'm two hundred and five, truth be told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flirtatiously) You don't look a day over one hundred and five, Captain. What's your secret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of carrot juice, little lady. That, and a deal with the Devil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a lot of murmuring in the room now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what exactly are you saying? Are we in cahoots with the Dark Master here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cultists get tense, start to leave en masse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! It's not that bad! When we get into Malkovich, we still get to rule the world, just like I told you. The  only difference is that we rule in the name of evil, instead of good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People stop in their tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the only difference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cultists think about is, then shrug and stay put.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So anyway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I for one, am resigning. I will not serve evil. I am ashamed of all of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear, let me assure you that when we attain power, it will be much more pleasant for those inside Malkovich, than for those outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte stops and turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take my chances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we get to wear a crown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. I think its time to beckon Mr. Flemmer. Perhaps He can help us out of this pickle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Flemmer, a silver-haired gentleman in turtleneck and blazer, scratches his head. The cultists patiently watch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, this is a toughie. To be honest, I didn't anticipate this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as I said, sir, we can't very well exert physical persuasion upon the sacred vessel Malkovich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, Lester. I heard you the first time. I'm not a dummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't mean to imply that you were, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm going back to my house to ponder this. So stay calm and keep track of Schwartz's comings and goings. Oh, and somebody dispose of Schwartz's wife, will you? (to cultists) Nice to meet you all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cult members ad-lib "same here, sir."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte site in the living room, in her pajamas, softly sobbing. The caged animals watch her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my friends. Be thankful you're not human. People are treacherous and greedy and corrupt. I've lost my heart to two of them and I almost lost my soul to another. And I'm no better. Look at the way I keep you, locked in cages, for my own enjoyment. Well, I've been in a cage too, my friends. Literally and figuratively. So tonight I set you free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte opens the windows and the front door, then unlocks all the cages. The animals scurry and fly out of their cages, and out of the house. Lotte watches silently until she is alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-bye, friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand reaches for hers. She looks down. Elijah is still there and holding her hand. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, friend

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the menagerie of animals on the otherwise deserted street, dispersing into the night. A lone dark figure tur the corner, and walks slowly up the street to Craig and Lotte's building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte and Elijah see the dark figure coming up the steps. The buzzer rings. Lotte and Elijah jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've come to kill me, Elijah. See, I know too much. I should get the door. It's impolite to keep death waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elijah looks at her sweetly, a great sadness in his eyes. Then he leads her by the hand out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marquee reads:  World's Greatest Puppeteer Craig Schwartz and his Magical Puppet John Malkovich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich sits in a tuxedo and watches himself in the dressing table mirror. Maxine, in a tight black number, reclines on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it, lover. You're stepping onto that stage a nobody and presto-change-o, you're coming back the greatest puppeteer the world has ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm nervous. Malkovich is fighting me hard today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich jerks a bit, gets it under control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't he know how important tonight is to us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a selfish bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is filling with formally dressed audience membe The cultists and Lester, also in tuxes and gowns, are amo them. The lights go down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, it is the great privilege of the Luxor hotel and Casino to present Craig Schwartz and his magical puppet John Malkovich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orchestra starts up. The curtains part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blasphemous bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich tap dances out onto the stage. He is amazingly nimble and the audience "oohs" and "aahs."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grudgingly) Pretty good though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich does an amazing triple somersault, lands on one knee and, with spread arms, begins singing: "Kiss Today Goodbye."  in a beautiful tenor. The orchestra catches up with him. The audience goes wild. A pretty-boy young man with a big tousle of black hair and a shiny, tight suit appears at the back of the house. An usher glances over a him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Mantini! We weren't expecting you tonight, sir. Um, I'm afraid there's not an empty seat in the entire house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not taking his eyes from the stage) Make one empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y-y-y-es sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usher looks nervously around for someone to boot. Martini waits in the back. On stage, Malkovich is now performing the "back of the car scene" from "On The Waterfront."  He alternates between the Marlon Brando par and the Rod Steiger part, moving back and forth from one stool to the another. He performs it magnificently. We se Lester in the audience wiping a small tear from his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too shabby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mantini is now sitting in a good aisle seat next to a  beautiful woman. Her boyfriend is being hauled toward the exit by the usher. The beautiful woman watches, with some concern, as the boyfriend is taken away. Then she turns a smiles flirtatiously at Mantini. Mantini smiles back. On stage Malkovich is dressed in a ringmaster's outfit and juggling chainsaws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing more than a Goddamn clown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point the entire audience stands and gives Malkov a spontaneous standing ovation. All except Mantini. Even cultists get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte sits sadly in the wet tunnel. She is scrunched-up against the damp cold. A small fire smolders in front of her. We hear footsteps approaching. It is Elijah, carryin supplies:  food and blankets. He covers her with a blanke and sits down next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to take over the world, Elijah. Evil will reign. But, then, evil already reigns, doesn't it? So what difference does it make if John Malkovich is wearing the fucking crown while it's reigning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elijah sighs, then holds his stomach. The ulcer is returning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a conservatively furnished upper westside apartment. Looks like it belongs to a Columbia professor. The walls are lined with books. Mr. Flemmer sits at his desk, his head in his hands, deep in thought. The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Lester pokes his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just me, boss. I brought croissants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester enters with a greasy white paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat. I wracking my brain over this Malkovich thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We saw his show at the Luxor last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed) Vegas? What'd you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid's got talent. You've never seen Malkovich like this. Schwartz had him up there singing and dancing. Impressions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impressions? Those are hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very talented son of a bitch. Too bad we can't kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose I could come to him in a dream. I don't know. That's the best I can think of right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scary dream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, a sexy dream. Of course, a scary dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (noncommittally) I like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich sits on the floor in silk pajamas. He is surrounded by newspaper clippings. He is drinking champagne from the bottle. Maxine is at a dressing table, brushing her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They love me, darling! "Craig Schwartz is fantastic!"  The New York Times. "If only Craig Schwartz had always been inside Malkovich!"  Women's Wear Daily. "Craig Schwartz - The world's greatest puppeteer!"  Paul Wunder, WBAI Radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, darling. It's a dream come true. We're going to ride this straight to the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleepy suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busy day, my little fire chief. Why don't you climb into bed, and I'll meet you there in just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Malkovich is already passed out on the floor on top o his clippings. Maxine smiles maternally, gets up and puts blanket over him. We stay on Malkovich's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig wanders across a jagged, rocky landscape. Geysers o flame shoot up around him. The sky is red. He is frighten He arrives at a desk. The man behind the desk is facing a from him. He swivels to face Craig. It is Flemmer, lookin the same as usual except for little red horns and a sinis grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the Devil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave Malkovich. He is mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Sorry. I didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich awakes with a start. Maxine looks over at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad dream, darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to leave Malkovich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to be kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just had the most horrifying nightmare. The devil was in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flemmer crouches behind a bureau and listens. He is pleas with himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich is our meal ticket. You can't back out because of some stupid dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, we can be happy and poor together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs derisively) Perhaps you'll want to consult that Ouija board again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock at the door. Maxine opens it, angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah what?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derek Mantini!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mantini enters. Maxine is suddenly interested. Mantini an Maxine give each other the once over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still eyeing Maxine) Hello, Schwartz. I saw your show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see the reviews?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I saw them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if you missed any, I just happen to have copies here you can take with you when you leave now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Maxine. I produced the evening with Malkovich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very impressive. I could use a producer with your vision. And other outstanding attributes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see, Schwartz. We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we'll see, Schwartz. We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't waste your time Schwartz, or more importantly, mine. Here's my proposal: There's only room in this world for one "World's Greatest Puppeteer."  Correct? So let's allow the puppet-going public to crown their king.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A friendly competition, if you will. Your Malkovich puppet and my Harry S. Truman puppet appear opposite each other in a play. Not some Vegas Burly-Q pyrotechnics, but a real play that requires actual acting. The audience decides who is more deserving of the title. The losing puppeteer bows out graciously. Goes back to obscurity as a file clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say... "Equus"? It's got everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broadway's finest three hours. It's about the suppression of the individual. Conformity as God in modern society.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds boring. Are there any songs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing but acting to hide behind, buddy-boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid. I toured for a year with the National Puppet Company's production of "Long Day's Journey Into Night."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there dancing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who needs dancing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester is watering Flemmer's plants. A key is heard in th door. Flemmer enters, a small carry-on bag slung over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd it go? Did you say the philodendron gets water or no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, for God's sake, I just watered it yesterday. (beat) It almost went well. I gave a pretty good dream, but circumstances arose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of circumstances?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maxine says she'll leave him if he leaves Malkovich, plus he's been challenged to a puppet-duel by Mantini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Great Mantini?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the Mediocre Mantini. Of course the Great Mantini!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he's good! Great, actually. I saw him do "Tru" with his sixty foot Robert Morse puppet. Sensational.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I think I have another plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snippy) Do tell. I love a good plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you being like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I missed you. I'm sorry. Tell me the plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if Mantini wins, Schwartz will leave Malkovich, right? So, if he needs it, I help Mantini's performance a bit, give him an edge. Spice up the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you do that? I mean, do you know anything about puppetry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the Devil, Lester. I think I can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just asking. No disrespect intended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Let's drop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I mean, it's not like I was doubting you, it's just that I know puppetry is a skill that takes a long time to acquire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I'm not mad. Let's just drop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Your mail's on the kitchen table. Mostly junk. Oh, there's a letter from Alex Trebek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte and Elijah, now dirty and drawn, are talking. Elija uses sign language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to tell Craig what's going on. He must never leave Malkovich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you learned sign language, Elijah, but I'm tired of your nagging. I'm tired of this conversation. I'm tired period. What has the world ever done for me that I should feel personally responsible for saving it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is better to light one candle than curse the darkness. I learned that from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte turns away, shaken. A tear rolls down her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have I become?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Marquee reads: Derek Mantini's sixty-foot Harry S. Truman puppet and Craig Schwartz's actual-size John Malkovich puppet in Peter Shaffer's "Equus."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is packed. On stage is a minimalist set: wood planks and metal poles. Six guys in brown turtlenecks and stylized wire horse heads mill about. The 60 foot Harry S Truman puppet is pacing, his strings extending up into th flyspace and out of sight. Malkovich sits on a bench. Tru and Malkovich both take stabs at British accents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you dream often?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my job to ask the questions. Yours to answer them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says me. Do you dream often?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the audience fidgeting in their seats, coughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dialogue drones on as Maxine watches coolly from the wings. She drags on a cigarette. Mr. Flemmer, dressed as a stagehand, stands behind Maxine. He also watches the actors, with an occasional sideways glance at Maxine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without turning around) Keep your eyes in your pants, old timer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's intermission. The lobby is crowded. Maxine moves through the crowd listening to snippets of conversation. Flemmer, now in a tuxedo, moves about also. First couple:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Truman puppet is downright boring as the psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a wooden performance, really. Get it? Wooden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second couple:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with the Malkovich puppet? He was much better in Vegas when he played the piano with his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate it when they try to stretch. It's like Woody Allen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third couple:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both stink! I'm going across the street to second act Miss Saigon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich watches himself in his dressing table mirror. Maxine enters, flops herself down on the couch and lights up a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better turn on the pyrotechnics, lover, 'cause right now you're running neck and neck with the dead president. And you're both in last place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich continues to watch himself in the mirror, nods head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mantini leans against a rail and smokes a cigarette. Char Nelson Reilly, in a tuxedo, confers with him in hushed to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing beautifully, my boy. I wept at the speech about your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flemmer materializes behind Mantini

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell? Nyong-nyong!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mantini spins around to face Flemmer. Reilly makes a brea for it. Flemmer points a finger and Reilly freezes in mid-strut. Flemmer then points a finger at Mantini, and h too, freezes. Flemmer picks up the giant wooden controls for the marionette, and pulls a copy of the play from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch the second act in progress. The Truman puppet pa as he delivers a monologue. Somehow he doesn't even seem be a puppet anymore, so subtle and graceful are his movements and the changes in his facial expressions. It's as if there's a giant actual Harry Truman on stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can hear the creature's voice. It's calling me out of the black cave of the Psyche. I shove in my dim little torch, and there he stands -- waiting for me. He raises his matted head. He opens his great, square teeth and says (mocking) 'Why? ... Why me? ... Why -- ultimately -- Me? ... Do you really imagine you can account for Me? Totally, infallibly, inevitably account for Me? ... Poor Dr. Dysart!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich watches impressed and a little scared by this bravura performance. He glances out into the audience and sees a silent, rapt crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich is delivering a monologue. Acting up a storm. During Malkovich's speech, Truman repeatedly attempts to upstage him, nodding his head, looking thoughtful, raisin his ten foot eyebrows in surprise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes! ... White eyes -- never closed! Eyes like flames -- coming -- coming! ... God seest! ... God seest! ... NO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man hole cover is pushed off. Lotte climbs out onto the street. She is dirty but determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich is in convulsions on the floor. Big dramatic convulsions. Truman scoops him up, and places him on the bench. Malkovich continues with the convulsions, milking it. Truman speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here ... Here ... Sssh ... Sssh ... Calm now ... Lie back. Just lie back! Now breathe in deep. Very deep. In ... Out ... In ... Out ... That's it ... In. Out .. In ... Out ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich is breathing insanely now, trying to keep the focus on himself. Flemmer is in the catwalks, watching th crowd. The audience is watching Malkovich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his wife) That Malkovich puppet is a damn fine actor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blood boiling) Bastard is stealing my thunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich and Truman on the stage. Truman is pacing, swirling, dancing, juggling enormous bowling pins as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! I'll take it away! He'll be delivered from madness. What then? He'll feel himself acceptable! What then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich has upPed his convulsions now. He watches Truma out of the corner of his eye while writhing tormentedly o the bench. He levitates. Spins in mid-air. Falls on all fours and does an uncanny impression of a yelping dog. Truman watches Malkovich, continues to speak. But now, wh he talks, fire comes out of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll heal the rash on his body. I'll erase the welts cut into his body by flying manes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience "ooohs" at the flames. Malkovich rips off hi clothes and convulses into the dying swan-bit from "Swan Lake." The audience applauds. Truman continues his speech now transforming himself into an actual 60 foot swan and flying around the auditorium as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't gallop anymore, Alan. Horses will be quite safe. You'll save your pennies every week, till you can change that scooter into a car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience watches the giant swan overhead, necks crane in awe. Malkovich sighs. He is out of his league. He goes into a remarkable tap dance routine and sings "Mr. Bojangles", but nobody even looks at the stage. The giant swan bursts into flames, flies back onto the stage, burns to a crisp, then rises from his ashes as the actual Harry Truman. Truman looks confused and disoriented, as if just raised from the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I? Aren't I dead? (possessed) Vote for Mantini!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman grows and grows until he is again just a giant puppet. The audience bursts into applause, then delivers standing ovation. Truman bows. Flemmer laughs wildly in t catwalks. Malkovich walks dejectedly from the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich walks past Maxine. She doesn't even look at him Thunderous applause is heard in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-bye, Maxine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich drops limply to the floor. He lifts his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weak but relieved) I'm back! My nightmare is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flemmer watches Malkovich from above. He pulls out a walkie-talkie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into walkie-talkie) Okay, now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester is surrounded by all the Malkovichians. He holds the walkie-talkie, has just received word. He nods, and the Malkovichians crawl in single file into the portal, while shrieking a war cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maxine watches as Malkovich pulls himself up off the grou Suddenly, he is again possessed, first by one person, the by two, then by three, his body jerking and pulsating wit each new occupant. It's almost like popping corn, startin out slowly, then going faster and faster, until Malkovich is possessed by all fifty Malkovichians. He shrieks a war cry and runs out onto the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Truman puppet now hangs limply from the catwalks. Malkovich hovers just above the stage and addresses the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (now sounding like fifty voices) I am your earthly king! Kneel before me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience scoffs at first, but then are compelled to their knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like automatons) Hail Malkovich, king of the damned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malkovich laughs, gives the thumbs up sign to Flemmer in the catwalks. Flemmer gives the thumbs up sign back. Lotte appears in the back of the theater, an out-of-breat figure in shadows. It is too late. She runs from the theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maxine watches, somewhat amused. She turns and heads for the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dejected Craig walks along the shoulder. He is wet and cold. We hold on him for a long while until he eventually merges with the landscape.

dialogues.speaker: CHYRON
dialogues.text: Something is wrong. It's a typical midtown street, but everything is painted gray:  the buildings, the streets, the sidewalks, the cars. People walk along the streets, carrying gray briefcases, wearing gray jumpsuits. Nobody talks, nobody smiles. Gray birds fly silently in the sky. There is no noise whatsoever. There are several movie theaters on the block. All marquees advertise John Malkov movies. Around the corner comes Malkovich. He is floating about ten feet off the ground on an enormous, bright red, jeweled throne. He wears a gold crown and purple silk rob and smiles condescendingly, majestically. Floris sits on lap. She is dressed in an orange satin gown. Nobody on th street looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fifty voices) Greetings, my lowly subjects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great things, my lonely subtext?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rolls his eyes) Boy, be careful what you wish for. (to Floris) Never mind, dear. Just enjoy the ride, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floris shrugs, picks at her finger nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the people on the street) I am bored. You will dance for your king now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without pause the entire street of gray clad people break into a meticulously choreographed production number. Tota silent, totally joyless, but exquisitely executed. We see that Maxine is one of the anonymous dancers. Her face is void of expression. Malkovich laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faster! Faster, my little trained monkeys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd dances faster and faster. Older people fall ove exhausted, clutching their hearts. Nobody stops dancing t help, nobody dares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bird's eye view of the park. It's all painted gray. Every tree, every leaf. There's no sign of life. The camera mov in, through some gray trees and gray brush to:

dialogues.speaker: A LUSH GREEN OASIS CAMOUFLAGED ON THE TOP AND SIDES WITH
dialogues.text: This place is filled with life:  Colorful birds, lizards, cats, a rooster. All the animals are active, happy, but totally silent, as if they know the precariousness of the position. Lotte and Elijah sit among them. These are the animals that she freed earlier. Lotte and Elijah hold han and look into each other's eyes. We see that they both we gold bands. They are husband and wife. Elijah signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must you take this terrible demon on yourself, my love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm the only one. I have to enter Malkovich and destroy him from the inside. If not me, who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there was any way I could go in your place. But I'm only a monkey and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puts finger to his lips) Hush, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte slips into a gray jumpsuit. She stuffs a homemade b on her pocket. She and Elijah kiss passionately, then embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the animals) I'll be with you always, my friends. Who knows, maybe if I'm lucky, I'll rejoin you with wings and a beak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wings and a halo, my darling. Wings and a halo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte turns quickly. This is too much to bear. She descen into a storm drain. The animals stop what they're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Good-bye. Good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man-hole cover lifts. Lotte pokes her head out. The coa is clear. She emerges. Assumes the dead-eyed expression o the others, and enters the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte watches the floors change. After seven, she presses the emergency stop button. The elevator jerks to a halt. She picks up the crow bar in the corner, pries open the door. The 7 1/2 floor is gone. Nothing is there but pipes and wires and beams. She climbs out onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte searched the floor for some sign of the portal. It is nowhere to be found. There is a noise behind her. She turns with a start. It's Craig, ragged and ill-shaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so glad you're safe. You look really wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in love. For the first time. It's funny, but when it happens to you, there's no question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a lucky man. (beat) Do I know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Elijah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The iguana?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The monkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right. As long as you're happy. I'm sure he's a better lover than I ever was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A better friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I'm sorry for everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pecking him on the cheek) It's okay, Craig. It all worked out, in an odd sort of way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came up here looking for the portal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I was going to kill him from the inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yourself too in the process. God, you're so beautiful. Why couldn't I see that before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw it once. Now you see it again. That's life, isn't it? And you were up here to try the same thing, weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose. But they got here first, the lousy bastards. So now it's all over, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. There's a small community of us. We have a place they don't know about. We're happy. We'll keep trying to figure out a way. Come stay with us. Join the struggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have me, after all I've done to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People make mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm through with puppets, Lotte. I just want you to know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to be a farmer. I want to help things grow, to encourage life. Do you and your friends need a farmer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. We could really use a farmer. We'd be grateful for the help. (beat) Also, I think, you know, if you wouldn't mind too terribly, a little puppet show every once in a while, would do a lot to lift our spirits. You know, if you wouldn't mind too terribly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig's eyes well up with tears. Lotte looks at him sweet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh honey. It's gonna be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her arm around him and leads him toward the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Lotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We come on very close to Craig's arm as he lifts it to pu it around Lotte. We see a thin almost invisible filament. We follow it up, and discover that Craig is now a marionette being controlled from above by an emotionless Mantini in a gray jumpsuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Craig's voice) I can't wait to see where you and your friends live, Lotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful, Craig, like Eden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we see filaments attached to Mantini's arms, and w follow them up to find that Flemmer is controlling Mantin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One serpent, coming up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flemmer throws his head back and laughs. The camera moves into his mouth and down his throat, which, oddly enough, looks exactly like the membranous John Malkovich portal tunnel. MUSIC IN: "Put Your Hand Inside The Puppet Head" by They Might Be Giants. It plays throughout the credits.
